an8.57:0.3.eng: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods (1st)

an8.57:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an8.57:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.57:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an8.57:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an8.57:1.4.eng: They’re learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an8.57:1.5.eng: They have good friends, companions, and associates.

an8.57:1.6.eng: They have right view, possessing right perspective.

an8.57:1.7.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an8.57:1.7.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an8.57:1.8.pli: anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati;
an8.57:1.8.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an8.57:1.9.pli: dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti;
an8.57:1.9.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, they see how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an8.57:1.10.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an8.57:1.11.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an8.57:1.11.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an8.58:0.3.eng: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods (2nd)

an8.58:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an8.58:1.1.eng: “A mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.58:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu;
an8.58:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an8.58:1.4.eng: They’re learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an8.58:1.5.pli: āraddhavīriyo viharati thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.58:1.5.eng: They live with energy roused up. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an8.58:1.6.eng: They live in the wilderness, in remote lodgings.

an8.58:1.7.pli: aratiratisaho hoti, uppannaṃ aratiṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya viharati;
an8.58:1.7.eng: They prevail over desire and discontent, and live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.

an8.58:1.8.pli: bhayabheravasaho hoti, uppannaṃ bhayabheravaṃ abhibhuyya abhibhuyya viharati;
an8.58:1.8.eng: They prevail over fear and dread, and live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.

an8.58:1.9.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī;
an8.58:1.9.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an8.58:1.10.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an8.58:1.11.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an8.58:1.11.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an8.59:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, puggalā āhuneyyā pāhuneyyā dakkhiṇeyyā añjalikaraṇīyā anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa?
an8.59:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these eight individuals are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.59:1.3.pli: Sotāpanno, sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno, sakadāgāmī, sakadāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno, anāgāmī, anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno, arahā, arahattāya paṭipanno.
an8.59:1.3.eng: The stream-enterer and the one practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry. The once-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of once-return. The non-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of non-return. The perfected one, and the one practicing for perfection.

an8.59:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha puggalā āhuneyyā …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassāti.
an8.59:1.4.eng: These are the eight individuals who are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.59:2.2.eng: and four established in the fruit.

an8.59:3.4.eng: what is given to the Saṅgha is very fruitful.”

an8.6:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati.
an8.6:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around the eight worldly conditions.

an8.6:1.3.pli: Lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṃsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca.
an8.6:1.3.eng: Gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.

an8.6:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca ime aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattati.
an8.6:1.4.eng: These eight worldly conditions revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly conditions.

an8.6:2.1.pli: Assutavato, bhikkhave, puthujjanassa uppajjati lābhopi alābhopi yasopi ayasopi nindāpi pasaṃsāpi sukhampi dukkhampi.
an8.6:2.1.eng: An unlearned ordinary person encounters gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, and pleasure and pain.

an8.6:2.2.pli: Sutavatopi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa uppajjati lābhopi alābhopi yasopi ayasopi nindāpi pasaṃsāpi sukhampi dukkhampi.
an8.6:2.2.eng: And so does a learned noble disciple.

an8.6:2.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ko viseso ko adhippayāso kiṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanenā”ti?
an8.6:2.3.eng: What, then, is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an ordinary unlearned person?”

an8.6:2.4.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an8.6:2.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an8.6:3.1.pli: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an8.6:3.1.eng: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an8.6:3.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an8.6:3.4.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person encounters gain.

an8.6:3.7.pli: so ca kho anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an8.6:3.7.eng: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They don’t truly understand it.

an8.6:3.17.pli: tañca kho aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhamman’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an8.6:3.17.eng: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They don’t truly understand it.

an8.6:4.1.pli: Tassa lābhopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, alābhopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, yasopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, ayasopi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, nindāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, pasaṃsāpi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, sukhampi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, dukkhampi cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
an8.6:4.1.eng: So gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, and pleasure and pain occupy their mind.

an8.6:4.2.pli: So uppannaṃ lābhaṃ anurujjhati, alābhe paṭivirujjhati;
an8.6:4.2.eng: They favor gain and oppose loss.

an8.6:4.3.eng: They favor fame and oppose disgrace.

an8.6:4.4.eng: They favor praise and oppose blame.

an8.6:4.5.eng: They favor pleasure and oppose pain.

an8.6:4.6.pli: So evaṃ anurodhavirodhasamāpanno na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
an8.6:4.6.eng: Being so full of favoring and opposing, they’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

an8.6:4.7.eng: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.

an8.6:5.1.pli: Sutavato ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa uppajjati lābho.
an8.6:5.1.eng: A learned noble disciple encounters gain.

an8.6:5.4.pli: so ca kho anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an8.6:5.4.eng: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They truly understand it.

an8.6:5.14.pli: tañca kho aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhamman’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an8.6:5.14.eng: It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They truly understand it.

an8.6:6.1.pli: Tassa lābhopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, alābhopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, yasopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, ayasopi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, nindāpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, pasaṃsāpi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, sukhampi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, dukkhampi cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
an8.6:6.1.eng: So gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, and pleasure and pain don’t occupy their mind.

an8.6:6.2.pli: So uppannaṃ lābhaṃ nānurujjhati, alābhe nappaṭivirujjhati;
an8.6:6.2.eng: They don’t favor gain or oppose loss.

an8.6:6.3.eng: They don’t favor fame or oppose disgrace.

an8.6:6.4.eng: They don’t favor praise or oppose blame.

an8.6:6.5.eng: They don’t favor pleasure or oppose pain.

an8.6:6.6.pli: So evaṃ anurodhavirodhavippahīno parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi.
an8.6:6.6.eng: Having given up favoring and opposing, they’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

an8.6:6.7.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.

an8.6:6.8.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, viseso ayaṃ adhippayāso idaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ sutavato ariyasāvakassa assutavatā puthujjanenāti.
an8.6:6.8.eng: This is the difference between a learned noble disciple and an unlearned ordinary person.

an8.6:7.1.eng: Gain and loss, fame and disgrace,

an8.6:7.2.eng: blame and praise, and pleasure and pain.

an8.6:7.3.eng: These qualities among mankind are impermanent,

an8.6:8.1.eng: An intelligent and mindful person knows these things,

an8.6:8.3.eng: Desirable things don’t disturb their mind,

an8.6:8.4.eng: nor are they repelled by the undesirable.

an8.6:9.2.eng: are cleared and disappeared, they are no more.

an8.6:9.4.eng: they who have gone beyond rebirth <j>understand rightly.”

an8.60:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, puggalā āhuneyyā …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an8.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these eight individuals are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.60:1.3.pli: Sotāpanno, sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno …pe… arahā, arahattāya paṭipanno.
an8.60:1.3.eng: The stream-enterer and the one practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry. The once-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of once-return. The non-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of non-return. The perfected one, and the one practicing for perfection.

an8.60:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha puggalā āhuneyyā …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassāti.
an8.60:1.4.eng: These are the eight individuals who are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.60:2.2.eng: and four established in the fruit.

an8.60:2.4.eng: the eight individuals among sentient beings.

an8.60:3.4.eng: what’s given here is very fruitful.”

an8.61:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these eight individuals are found in the world.

an8.61:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:1.3.eng: First, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:1.4.eng: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:1.5.pli: Tassa uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato lābhāya lābho nuppajjati.
an8.61:1.5.eng: But material things don’t come to them.

an8.61:1.6.pli: So tena alābhena socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an8.61:1.6.eng: And so they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion because they don’t get those material things.

an8.61:1.8.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, uṭṭhahati ghaṭati vāyamati lābhāya, na ca lābhī, socī ca paridevī ca, cuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:1.8.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. But when they do not acquire material things, they sorrow and lament. They’ve fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:2.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:2.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:2.2.eng: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:2.3.pli: Tassa uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato lābhāya lābho uppajjati.
an8.61:2.3.eng: And material things do come to them.

an8.61:2.4.pli: So tena lābhena majjati pamajjati pamādamāpajjati.
an8.61:2.4.eng: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those material things.

an8.61:2.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, uṭṭhahati ghaṭati vāyamati lābhāya, lābhī ca madī ca pamādī ca, cuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:2.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. And when they acquire material things, they become intoxicated and negligent. They’ve fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:3.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:3.2.pli: So na uṭṭhahati na ghaṭati na vāyamati lābhāya.
an8.61:3.2.eng: They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:3.3.pli: Tassa anuṭṭhahato aghaṭato avāyamato lābhāya lābho nuppajjati.
an8.61:3.3.eng: And material things don’t come to them.

an8.61:3.4.pli: So tena alābhena socati, kilamati, paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an8.61:3.4.eng: And so they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion because they don’t get those material things.

an8.61:3.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, na uṭṭhahati na ghaṭati na vāyamati lābhāya, na ca lābhī, socī ca paridevī ca, cuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:3.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. And when they do not acquire material things, they sorrow and lament. They’ve fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:4.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:4.2.pli: So na uṭṭhahati, na ghaṭati, na vāyamati lābhāya.
an8.61:4.2.eng: They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:4.3.pli: Tassa anuṭṭhahato, aghaṭato, avāyamato lābhāya lābho uppajjati.
an8.61:4.3.eng: But material things do come to them.

an8.61:4.4.pli: So tena lābhena majjati, pamajjati, pamādamāpajjati.
an8.61:4.4.eng: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those material things.

an8.61:4.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, na uṭṭhahati na ghaṭati na vāyamati lābhāya, lābhī ca madī ca, pamādī ca, cuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:4.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. But when they acquire material things, they become intoxicated and negligent. They’ve fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:5.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:5.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:5.2.eng: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:5.3.pli: Tassa uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato lābhāya lābho nuppajjati.
an8.61:5.3.eng: But material things don’t come to them.

an8.61:5.4.pli: So tena alābhena na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an8.61:5.4.eng: But they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion because they don’t get those material things.

an8.61:5.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, uṭṭhahati ghaṭati vāyamati lābhāya, na ca lābhī, na ca socī na ca paridevī, accuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:5.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. But when they do not acquire material things, they don’t sorrow and lament. They haven’t fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:6.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:6.2.eng: They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:6.3.pli: Tassa uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato lābhāya lābho uppajjati.
an8.61:6.3.eng: And material things do come to them.

an8.61:6.4.pli: So tena lābhena na majjati, na pamajjati, na pamādamāpajjati.
an8.61:6.4.eng: But they don’t become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those material things.

an8.61:6.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, uṭṭhahati ghaṭati vāyamati lābhāya, lābhī ca, na ca madī na ca pamādī, accuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:6.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. But when they acquire material things, they don’t become intoxicated and negligent. They haven’t fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:7.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:7.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:7.2.pli: So na uṭṭhahati, na ghaṭati, na vāyamati lābhāya.
an8.61:7.2.eng: They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:7.3.pli: Tassa anuṭṭhahato, aghaṭato, avāyamato lābhāya lābho nuppajjati.
an8.61:7.3.eng: And material things don’t come to them.

an8.61:7.4.pli: So tena alābhena na socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an8.61:7.4.eng: But they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion because they don’t get those material things.

an8.61:7.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, na uṭṭhahati, na ghaṭati, na vāyamati lābhāya, na ca lābhī, na ca socī na ca paridevī, accuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:7.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. And when they do not acquire material things, they don’t sorrow and lament. They haven’t fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:8.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno pavivittassa viharato nirāyattavuttino icchā uppajjati lābhāya.
an8.61:8.1.eng: Next, when a mendicant stays secluded, living independently, a desire arises for material things.

an8.61:8.2.pli: So na uṭṭhahati, na ghaṭati, na vāyamati lābhāya.
an8.61:8.2.eng: They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them.

an8.61:8.3.pli: Tassa anuṭṭhahato aghaṭato avāyamato lābhāya lābho uppajjati.
an8.61:8.3.eng: But material things do come to them.

an8.61:8.4.pli: So tena lābhena na majjati, na pamajjati, na pamādamāpajjati.
an8.61:8.4.eng: But they don’t become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those material things.

an8.61:8.6.pli: ‘bhikkhu iccho viharati lābhāya, na uṭṭhahati, na ghaṭati, na vāyamati lābhāya, lābhī ca, na ca madī na ca pamādī, accuto ca saddhammā’.
an8.61:8.6.eng: a mendicant who lives desiring material things. They don’t try hard, strive, and make an effort to get them. And when they acquire material things, they don’t become intoxicated and negligent. They haven’t fallen from the true teaching.

an8.61:9.1.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an8.61:9.1.eng: These are the eight individuals found in the world.”
